textPlain: Yeah, I bookmark stuff, but just in my browser. No apps or extensions — keeping it simple.
Yeah, otherwise I'd end up with 9000 tabs. I use firefox and make use of the tagging system there, it's nice.

Yes I heavily use bookmarks. I got back into it a few years ago when I quit going to large forums like Reddit and needed a way to remember important URLs I knew I'd want later.I keep them in an HTML file in git along with all my dot files.

After years of jumping between different platforms and systems I've landed on linkhut [0]. I like that it's social by default and chronological-oriented, with flexible but really basic options for organization (tags and 'read later' flag). It makes it so that bookmarking neat things actually feels like it has a point, even if I don't always organize them in a way I can easily find later.[0] https://linkhut.org/
I still use traditional browser-based bookmarking, and sync with my Firefox account. I don't see the need to share my bookmarks.
I use floccus to sync my bookmarks to my nextcloud. Especially on the phone its useful, since accessing my bookmarks in firefox for android is a hassle.
I use an ever expanding text file, plus bookmarks. The textfile is #1 for me, and can live on various drives.
Yes I still use bookmarks, though it's tempting to have chatgpt5 build me a memex so I can save whole pages and sites and mark them up to save in a journal instead.

Of course. I bookmark them using bookmarks in my browser. I have about 15k bookmarks now. I also save my session files so I have tabs with history too. For both bookmarks and tab session files I have perl scripts to process/search them.

Honestly, since the first day I switched to Firefox I'm just saving to it's own bookmarks. Whenever I wanna check those websites I just open it either from my desktop or my laptop(s), since it's syncing in between my devices.I don't know if there's much people using bookmarking tools, but to help you see another perspective, as a person who finds bookmarking tools not necessary I'd say it wouldn't worth your time to vibe code one. Also just for "vibe coding", be really really careful if you're gonna make it a "product" because you'll definitely face rough situations through it.

Another shot at a bookmark manager is welcome.The usual story is "I bookmarked 20,000 web pages over 3 years and then I realized I never looked at any of them!"I built an "image sorter" which used to ingest image galleries using a bookmarklet which would queue the galleries to get crawled with a web crawler,  I would then classify and rank the image galleries in an HTMX-based UI.  I really do look at the images every day so it is successful in that sense.  The web crawler started running into Cloudflare problems so now I save the whole page with the browser and have a Python script harvest the pages out of my Downloads folder.
Yes, honestly I still do that! I know it's old school. But it works. easy to use, fast access and free, lool!
do you use an extension to interactively save the links?
The sync is a major issue. If I save them on my desktop's Chrome, then my iPhone's Safari does not know those.
Interesting. I would want something similar -- like an old school web annotator but kinda automated.
15K :oThat is some number. Mine would have been similar, but they got lost as I moved between tools.
If I do one, it would be for personal use.Because the moment it evolves into publicly available, then it would suck me into the dopamine of adding features for others :-)
